body:
Thanks @DanielSchiavini for the report.

I did some investigation and found that `<Package 'lib'>` and `<Package 'lib/tests'>` both are collecting `<Module 'TestPyTest.py'>` from `lib/tests/TestPyTest.py`... I would need more time to investigate than I have right now, I'm afraid.

I looked into this and the problem is in the Package.collect() code. I based my logic on a bad assumption that `__init__.py` would always come first when iterating through filesystem. That's so wrong and this issue just proves it. Ugh!
Working on a fix now.

I'm getting this error, which might be the same cause as the issue mentioned above?
```
$ pytest -v astropy/table
/Users/deil/software/anaconda3/envs/gammapy-dev-37/lib/python3.7/importlib/_bootstrap.py:219: ImportWarning: can't resolve package from __spec__ or __package__, falling back on __name__ and __path__

================================================================================================= ERRORS ==================================================================================================

../../../software/anaconda3/envs/gammapy-dev-37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pluggy/hooks.py:258: in __call__

../../../software/anaconda3/envs/gammapy-dev-37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pluggy/manager.py:67: in _hookexec

../../../software/anaconda3/envs/gammapy-dev-37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pluggy/hooks.py:258: in __call__

../../../software/anaconda3/envs/gammapy-dev-37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pluggy/manager.py:67: in _hookexec
```

You should be able to reproduce via:
```
conda create --name trouble python=3.7 numpy cython pytest
conda activate trouble
git clone https://github.com/astropy/astropy.git
cd astropy
pytest -v astropy/table
```

Let me know if you can't reproduce, or if I should file a separate issue for this.

issue.title: Support Python 3.7

repository.name: gammapy
repository.description: A Python package for gamma-ray astronomy

issue.body:
Python 3.7 was released 2018-06-28 and now people will start to use it (e.g. I got it today by default when making a conda env).

I'll try to add a CI build for Python 3.7, to see if we can support it for v0.8 already.

Probably in Gammapy there's zero or very few changes needed, because Python 3.7 should be compatible with previous Python 3 releases, this is mostly a CI config / setup task.

Numpy and Astropy still support it in the latest stable releases, for regions it's being added at the moment (see https://github.com/astropy/regions/pull/208), for iminuit see https://github.com/iminuit/iminuit/issues/270 .

issue.title: SystemError: <class 'astropy.io.ascii.cparser.FastWriter'> returned NULL without setting an error

labels.name: Close?
labels.description: Tell stale bot that this issue/PR is stale

issue.body:
I'm getting this error when trying to write a file out using:

     ascii.write(data, 'name.dat', format='csv', overwrite=True)

It appears to be related to this  `cython` [closed issue](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2043).  Removing `format='csv'` makes the issue go away.

body:
Hi @cdeil,

I could not reproduce your issue on Ubuntu 18, latest conda and a fresh clone:

```
 1472 passed, 10 skipped, 11 xfailed, 5 error in 58.53 seconds
```

All the errors I got was the error about `tree` fixture being called directly:

```
    @pytest.fixture
    def bst():
>       return tree()
E       _pytest.deprecated.RemovedInPytest4Warning: Fixture tree called directly. Fixtures are not meant to be called directly, are created automatically when test functions request them as parameters. See https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/fixture.html for more information.
```

The fix for that by the way is to change `bst` to:

```python
    @pytest.fixture
    def bst(tree):
        return tree
```


Either way could you please open a new issue? It doesn't seem to be the issue as the one described here.
For that fix I've opened https://github.com/astropy/astropy/pull/7769 already.

issue.title: Fix #3854

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
If a test was found in a file that started with a capital letter within a subpackage of a package pytest would collect it twice.

Fix #3796, fix #3854

issue.title: Is a Python 3.7 test running on travis-ci?

labels.name: Close?
labels.description: Tell stale bot that this issue/PR is stale

issue.body:
I wanted to add a Python 3.7 build on travis-ci for Gammapy a few days ago (see https://github.com/gammapy/gammapy/issues/1724) but was running into several issues with pytest (see  https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/3854#issuecomment-415671196) and also Astropy.

Currently with Astropy master e.g.
```
pytest -v astropy/stats/lombscargle/tests/test_statistics.py
```
locally for me takes several minutes (?!) and then fails like this:
```
96 failed, 78 passed in 339.38 seconds
```

I wanted to understand this, and see if the issues also appear in the Astropy travis-ci builds.

As far as I can see, there's only this Python 3.7 build, and it's not running the tests!?
https://travis-ci.org/astropy/astropy/jobs/420715129#L480

Most of the other tests also don't seem to run the tests or a docs build and only take 1 minute:
https://travis-ci.org/astropy/astropy/builds/420715127

@bsipocz @astrofrog - Is there a problem with the Astropy travis-ci setup, or am I just not understanding how it works / looking at the wrong builds?
